newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Hong Kong stocks close down, profit-taking pares record.
newsitem.headline: Hong Kong stocks close down, profit-taking pares record.

text.p: Hong Kong stocks ended Wednesday's session sharply lower, after a morning surge to a new intra-day record high prompted investors to take profits during the afternoon, brokers said.
The Hang Seng index closed 94.52 points lower at 12,396.18, well off the intra-day record of 12,602.34 hit earlier.
The previous all-time intra-day high was 12,599.23 hit on January 4, 1994.
"I'm sure that what we have seen here is just a profit-taking session," said Miles Remington, sales trader at Crosby Securities.
Some brokers said rumours that First Pacific Co Ltd would place shares at a discount to its current market price sparked the profit-taking. First Pacific denied the rumours.

"The market obviously has risen very strongly over the last few days and needed to have a consolidation. The trigger of the consolidation was the rumour in the market of a possible placement of First Pacific. People used that as an excuse to top slice," said Remington.

Turnover soared to HK$9.142 billion, significantly higher than Tuesday's HK$8.41 billion. The total was lifted by a turnover in market favourite HSBC of HK$709.29 million, more than the share's average daily turnover.
HSBC closed unchanged at HK$151.50, after trading at a new all time high of HK$153.50.
Brokers said turnover was also enlarged by overseas brokers selling baskets of shares.
The market's correction is overdue, technical analysts said.
"This is only a temporary top," said Alex Wong,

"Over the next three to four days, we could see a 250 to 500-point retracement back to the 12,200 to 12,250 level," Wong said. "Daily indicators are still bullish but on the hourly chart indicators look very overbought."
Among the blue chips, properties took the greatest beating, followed by the commercial and industrial sector. Finance issues traded sideways, thus leading the market.
HSBC subsidiary Hang Seng Bank which has leaped ahead in active trading in recent days, shed only HK$0.25 to HK$92.50, after hitting a new high of HK$94.75.
